nexttext:
\noindent
where $e$ is the electronic charge, $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $f$ is the Fermi distribution function, and $M_ \textrm {DT}$ is the tunnelling matrix element between the single electron states of the dopant (denoted by the subscript $\textrm D$) and of the STM tip (denoted by the subscript $\textrm T$). As derived by Chen in Ref.~\onlinecite{Chen_PRB_1990} that the tunnelling matrix element, for all the cases related to STM measurements, can be reduced to a much simpler surface integral solved on a separation surface $\chi$ arbitrarily chosen at a point in-between the sample and STM tip. Therefore,

u}(1-f(E_{
u}+eV))|M_{	extrm{DT}}|^{2}%
	imes\delta(E_{\mu}-E_{
u}-eV)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>ν</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>DT</mtext></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>×</mo><mi>δ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>ν</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent
where $\Psi_ \textrm D$ is the single electron state of the sample (P or As dopant in Si), $\Psi_ \textrm T$ is the state of the single atom at the apex of the STM tip, and $d\chi$ is an element on the separation surface $\chi$. 

In our calculation of the STM images, we follow Chen's approach~\cite{Chen_PRB_1990}, which reduces equation~\ref{tm} to a very simple derivative rule where the tunnelling matrix element is simply proportional to a functional of the sample wave function computed at the tip location, $r_0$ (for $\chi$ assumed to be at the apex of the STM tip):

As derived by Chen in Ref.~\onlinecite{Chen_PRB_1990} that the tunnelling matrix element, for all the cases related to STM measurements, can be reduced to a much simpler surface integral solved on a separation surface $\chi$ arbitrarily chosen at a point in-between the sample and STM tip. In our calculation of the STM images, we follow Chen's approach~\cite{Chen_PRB_1990}, which reduces equation~\ref{tm} to a very simple derivative rule where the tunnelling matrix element is simply proportional to a functional of the sample wave function computed at the tip location, $r_0$ (for $\chi$ assumed to be at the apex of the STM tip):

nexttext: Although $C_{\rm P}$ is a direct comparison of the pixels in two images, it does not take into account the structure of images, $i.e.$ number, size, and intensity of the features inside an image. Therefore, we also define feature-by-feature correlation comparator $C_{\rm F}$, which takes into account both the structural information of the images and the intensity of the individual features in the images. The definition of the $C_{\rm F}$ comparator is as follows:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="C_{\rm P}=1-\left(\frac{\sum\limits_{x,y}^{N_{x},N_{y}}|I_{\rm exp}(x,y)-I_{%
\rm th}(x,y)|}{\sum\limits_{x,y}^{N_{x},N_{y}}I_{\rm exp}(x,y)}\right)" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></mrow></munderover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mi>exp</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mi>th</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></mrow></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mi>exp</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: Although $C_{\rm P}$ is a direct comparison of the pixels in two images, it does not take into account the structure of images, $i.e.$ number, size, and intensity of the features inside an image. Therefore, we also define feature-by-feature correlation comparator $C_{\rm F}$, which takes into account both the structural information of the images and the intensity of the individual features in the images. The definition of the $C_{\rm F}$ comparator is as follows:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="C_{\rm F}=\left(1-\frac{|N_{\rm F}^{exp}-N_{\rm F}^{th}|}{N_{\rm F}^{exp}}%
\right)\left(\frac{\sum\limits_{x,y}^{N_{\rm F}^{exp}}\sum\limits_{x,y}^{N_{%
\rm F}^{th}}[I_{\rm th}(x,y)I_{\rm exp}(x,y)]}{\sqrt{\sum\limits_{x,y}^{N_{\rm
F%
}^{th}}I_{\rm th}^{2}(x,y)\sum\limits_{x,y}^{N_{\rm F}^{exp}}I_{\rm exp}^{2}(x%
,y)}}\right)" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><msubsup><mi>N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></msubsup></munderover><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false"
